content.user_title: Build and Manage Claude Code Plugins
content.value_statement: Creating Claude Code plugins requires proper directory structure, manifest files, and version management. This skill automates plugin scaffolding with scripts that generate correct plugin.json manifests, README templates, and handle semantic versioning across both plugin and marketplace manifests.
actual_capabilities: Generate complete plugin directory structure with a single command
Create properly formatted plugin.json and marketplace.json manifests
Bump semantic versions across both manifest files simultaneously
Provide reference documentation for plugin architecture and workflows
Support multiple plugin patterns: framework, utility, and domain plugins
Automate README generation with installation and usage templates
limitations: Requires local marketplace root directory to be initialized first
Does not validate plugin code quality or functionality
Version bumping requires manual git commit and tag creation

use_cases.title: Plugin Developer Onboarding
use_cases.description: New developers use the scaffold script to create their first Claude Code plugin with proper structure, avoiding common manifest errors and ensuring marketplace compatibility from day one.
use_cases.target_user: Developers building their first Claude Code plugin

use_cases.title: Marketplace Maintenance
use_cases.description: Maintainers use bump_version.py to ensure version consistency across plugin.json and marketplace.json during releases, preventing version drift and installation issues.

use_cases.title: Team Plugin Standardization
use_cases.description: Engineering teams use the skill to enforce consistent plugin structure across multiple internal plugins, ensuring all team members follow the same conventions and patterns.
use_cases.target_user: Engineering teams with multiple internal plugins

prompt_templates.title: Create a New Plugin
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new Claude Code plugin called 'my-plugin' for the marketplace at /path/to/marketplace. The author is 'John Doe' with email 'john@example.com'. The plugin is described as 'A productivity plugin for task management' with keywords 'productivity, tasks, management' and category 'productivity'.

prompt_templates.title: Bump Plugin Version
prompt_templates.prompt: Bump the version of plugin 'my-plugin' in marketplace /path/to/marketplace. Use a minor version bump for the new feature I'm adding.

prompt_templates.title: Add Component to Plugin
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to add a new command to my existing plugin. Show me the correct directory structure and file format for adding a '/docs:generate' command that creates documentation from code comments.

prompt_templates.title: Plugin Architecture Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my plugin structure at /path/to/plugin and compare it against the reference patterns. Identify any missing components or structural issues that might prevent marketplace registration.

output_examples.input: Create a new plugin called 'task-runner' with author 'Jane Smith', email 'jane@example.com', description 'Run automated tasks', keywords 'automation,tasks', category 'devops'
Bump version of plugin 'task-runner' with a minor bump

best_practices: Always use bump_version.py to update versions to ensure consistency between plugin.json and marketplace.json
Follow kebab-case naming convention for plugin names to ensure compatibility
Test plugins locally with /plugin install before submitting to shared marketplaces
anti_patterns: Do not manually edit version numbers in only one manifest file - this causes version drift
Avoid creating plugins directly in the marketplace without using the scaffold script - manual creation often misses required fields
Do not skip the local testing step - plugins with malformed manifests can cause installation failures

faq.question: What is the difference between plugin.json and marketplace.json?
faq.answer: plugin.json lives inside your plugin directory and describes the plugin itself. marketplace.json is the registry that lists all available plugins in a marketplace. Both are required for a plugin to be installable.

faq.question: Can I use this skill to publish to the official Claude Code marketplace?
faq.answer: This skill helps you prepare plugins for any marketplace. For the official marketplace, you will need to follow the specific submission process documented by Anthropic after using this skill to create your plugin structure.

faq.question: What plugin patterns are supported?
faq.answer: The skill supports three patterns: Framework plugins for framework-specific guidance, Utility plugins for tools and commands, and Domain plugins for domain-specific knowledge. Each has a recommended directory structure documented in the references.

faq.question: How do I test my plugin before publishing?
faq.answer: Use the /plugin marketplace add command to add your local marketplace root, then install your plugin with /plugin install plugin-name@marketplace-name. Make changes, uninstall, and reinstall to test updates.

faq.question: What happens if I forget to bump the version?
faq.answer: Claude Code may cache the old version. Always bump the version when making changes, even for documentation updates, to ensure users get the latest version.

faq.question: Can I convert an existing skill into a plugin?
faq.answer: Yes. Create a new plugin structure, then move your SKILL.md into the skills/ directory. Update the plugin.json with appropriate metadata and register it in marketplace.json.
